But whenever I think about mine errors, I am like to cover my lips for shame.--Here she (daughter) looked up and smiled.--Its a strange thing now--I hae spoke mair gude words to you in ten minutes, than I wad speak to my mother in as mony years--its no that I dinna think on them--and whiles they are just at my tongues end, but then comes the devil, and brushes my lips with his (devil) black wing, and lays his (devil) broad black loof on my mouth--for a black loof it is, Jeanie--and sweeps away a my gude thoughts, and dits up my gude words, and pits a wheen fule sangs and idle vanities in their place. Try, Madge, said Jeanie,--try to settle your mind and make your breast clean, and youll find your heart easier.--Just resist the devil, and he (devil) will flee from you--and mind that, as my worthy father tells me, there is nae devil sae deceitfu as our ain wandering thoughts. And thats true too, lass, said Madge, starting up; and Ill gang a gate where the devil daurna follow me; and its a gate that you will like dearly to gang--but Ill keep a fast haud o your arm, for fear Apollyon should stride across the path, as he (devil) did in the Pilgrims Progress. Accordingly she (Madge) got up, and, taking Jeanie by the arm, began to walk forward at a great pace; and soon, to her (Jeanie) companions no small joy, came into a marked path, with the meanders of which she (Jeanie) seemed perfectly acquainted. Jeanie endeavoured to bring her (Jeanie) back to the confessional, but the fancy was gone by. In fact, the mind of this deranged being resembled nothing so much as a quantity of dry leaves, which may for a few minutes remain still, but are instantly discomposed and put in motion by the first casual breath of air. She (Jeanie) had now got John Bunyans parable into her (Jeanie) head, to the exclusion of everything else, and on she (Jeanie) went with great volubility. Did ye never read the Pilgrims Progress? And you shall be the woman, Christiana, and I will be the maiden, Mercy--for ye ken Mercy was of the fairer countenance, and the more alluring than her (Christiana) companion--and if I had my little messan dog here, it would be Great-heart, their guide, ye ken, for he (ken) was een as bauld, that he (ken) wad bark at ony thing twenty times his (ken) size; and that was een the death of him (ken), for he (ken) bit Corporal MacAlpines heels ae morning when they were hauling me to the guard-house, and Corporal MacAlpine killed the bit faithfu thing wi his (Corporal) Lochaber axe--deil pike the Highland banes o him (Corporal). O fie! Madge, said Jeanie, ye should not speak such words. Its very true, said Madge, shaking her (Madge) head; but then I maunna think o my puir bit doggie, Snap, when I saw it lying dying in the gutter. But its just as weel, for it suffered baith cauld and hunger when it was living, and in the grave there is rest for a things--rest for the doggie, and my puir bairn, and me. Your bairn? said Jeanie, conceiving that by speaking on such a topic, supposing it to be a real one, she (Jeanie) could not fail to bring her (Jeanie) companion to a more composed temper.

She (Jeanie) was mistaken, however, for Madge coloured, and replied with some anger, _My_ bairn? ay, to be sure, my bairn. Whatfor shouldna I hae a bairn and lose a bairn too, as weel as your bonnie tittie, the Lily of St. Leonards? The answer struck Jeanie with some alarm, and she (Jeanie) was anxious to soothe the irritation she (Jeanie) had unwittingly given occasion to. I am very sorry for your misfortune. Sorry! what wad ye be sorry for? answered Madge. The bairn was a blessing--that is, Jeanie, it wad hae been a blessing if it hadna been for my mother; but my mothers a queer woman.--Ye see, there was an auld carle wi a bit land, and a gude clat o siller besides, just the very picture of old Mr. Feeblemind or Mr. Ready-to-halt, that Great-heart delivered from Slaygood the giant, when he (Mr.) was rifling him (Mr.) and about to pick his (Mr.) bones, for Slaygood was of the nature of the flesh-eaters--and Great-heart killed Giant Despair too--but I am doubting Giant Despairs come alive again, for a the story book--I find him (Mr.) busy at my heart whiles. Weel, and so the auld carle, said Jeanie, for she (Jeanie) was painfully interested in getting to the truth of Madges history, which she (Madge) could not but suspect was in some extraordinary way linked and entwined with the fate of her (Madge) sister. She (Madge) was also desirous, if possible, to engage her (Madge) companion in some narrative which might be carried on in a lower tone of voice, for she (Madge) was in great apprehension lest the elevated notes of Madges conversation should direct her (Madge) mother or the robbers in search of them. And so the auld carle, said Madge, repeating her (Madge) words--I wish ye had seen him (companion) stoiting about, aff ae leg on to the other, wi a kind o dot-and-go-one sort o motion, as if ilk ane o his (companion) twa legs had belanged to sindry folk--but Gentle George could take him (George) aff brawly--Eh, as I used to laugh to see George gang hip-hop like him (George)!--I dinna ken, I think I laughed heartier then than what I do now, though maybe no just sae muckle. And who was Gentle George? said Jeanie, endeavouring to bring her (Jeanie) back to her (Jeanie) story. O, he (George) was Geordie Robertson, ye ken, when he (Robertson) was in Edinburgh; but thats no his (Robertson) right name neither--His (Robertson) name is--But what is your business wi his (Robertson) name? said she (Jeanie), as if upon sudden recollection, What have ye to do asking for folks names?--Have ye a mind I should scour my knife between your ribs, as my mother says? As this was spoken with a menacing tone and gesture, Jeanie hastened to protest her (Jeanie) total innocence of purpose in the accidental question which she (Jeanie) had asked, and Madge Wildfire went on somewhat pacified. Never ask folks names, Jeanie--its no civil--I hae seen half-a-dozen o folk in my mothers at ance, and neer ane a them cad the ither by his (ye) name; and Daddie Ratton says, it is the most uncivil thing may be, because the bailie bodies are aye asking fashions questions, when ye saw sic a man, or sic a man; and if ye dinna ken their names, ye ken there can be nae mair speerd about it. In what strange school, thought Jeanie to herself, has this poor creature been bred up, where such remote precautions are taken against the pursuits of justice? What would my father or Reuben Butler think if I were to tell them there are sic folk in the world? And to abuse the simplicity of this demented creature! Oh, that I were but safe at hame amang mine ain leal and true people! and Ill bless God, while I have breath, that placed me amongst those who live in His (God) fear, and under the shadow of His (God) wing. She (father) was interrupted by the insane laugh of Madge Wildfire, as she (Wildfire) saw a magpie hop across the path. See there!--that was the gate my auld joe used to cross the country, but no just sae lightly--he (joe) hadna wings to help his (joe) auld legs, I trow; but I behoved to have married him (joe) for a that, Jeanie, or my mother wad hae been the dead o me. But then came in the story of my poor bairn, and my mother thought he (joe) wad be deaved wi its skirling, and she (mother) pat it away in below the bit bourock of turf yonder, just to be out o the gate; and I think she (mother) buried my best wits with it, for I have never been just mysell since. And only think, Jeanie, after my mother had been at a these pains, the auld doited body Johnny Drottle turned up his (Johnny) nose, and wadna hae aught to say to me! But its little I care for him (Johnny), for I have led a merry life ever since, and neer a braw gentleman looks at me but ye wad think he (gentleman) was gaun to drop off his (gentleman) horse for mere love of me. I have kend some o them put their hand in their pocket, and gie me as muckle as sixpence at a time, just for my weel-faured face. This speech gave Jeanie a dark insight into Madges history. She (Jeanie) had been courted by a wealthy suitor, whose addresses her (Jeanie) mother had favoured, notwithstanding the objection of old age and deformity. She (Jeanie) had been seduced by some profligate, and, to conceal her (Jeanie) shame and promote the advantageous match she (Jeanie) had planned, her (Jeanie) mother had not hesitated to destroy the offspring of their intrigue. That the consequence should be the total derangement of amind which was constitutionally unsettled by giddiness and vanity, was extremely natural; and such was, in fact, the history of Madge Wildfires insanity.

CHAPTER SEVENTH.

So free from danger, free from fear They crossed the court--right glad they were. Christabel.

Pursuing the path which Madge had chosen, Jeanie Deans observed, to her (Deans) no small delight, that marks of more cultivation appeared, and the thatched roofs of houses, with their blue smoke arising in little columns, were seen embosomed in a tuft of trees at some distance. The track led in that direction, and Jeanie, therefore, resolved, while Madge continued to pursue it, that she (Madge) would ask her (Madge) no questions; having had the penetration to observe, that by doing so she (Madge) ran the risk of irritating her (Madge) guide, or awakening suspicions, to the impressions of which, persons in Madges unsettled state of mind are particularly liable.

Madge, therefore, uninterrupted, went on with the wild disjointed chat which her (Madge) rambling imagination suggested; a mood in which she (Madge) was much more communicative respecting her (Madge) own history, and that of others, than when there was any attempt made, by direct queries, or cross-examinations, to extract information on these subjects. Its a queer thing, she (Madge) said, but whiles I can speak about the bit bairn and the rest of it, just as if it had been another bodys, and no my ain; and whiles I am like to break my heart about it--Had you ever a bairn, Jeanie? Jeanie replied in the negative. Ay; but your sister had, though--and I ken what came ot too. In the name of heavenly mercy, said Jeanie, forgetting the line of conduct which she (Jeanie) had hitherto adopted, tell me but what became of that unfortunate babe, and-- Madge stopped, looked at her (Madge) gravely and fixedly, and then broke into a great fit of laughing--Aha, lass,--catch me if you can--I think its easy to gar you trow ony thing.--How suld I ken onything o your sisters wean? Lasses suld hae naething to do wi weans till they are married--and then a the gossips and cummers come in and feast as if it were the blithest day in the warld.--They say maidens bairns are weel guided. I wot that wasna true of your titties and mine; but these are sad tales to tell.--I maun just sing a bit to keep up my heart--Its a sang that Gentle George made on me lang syne, when I went with him (George) to Lockington wake, to see him (George) act upon a stage, in fine clothes, with the player folk. He (George) might hae dune waur than married me that night as he (George) promised--better wed over the mixen* as over the moor, as they say in Yorkshire--

* A homely proverb, signifying better wed a neighbour than one fetched from a distance.--Mixen signifies dunghill.

he (George) may gang farther and fare waur--but thats a ane to the sang, Im Madge of the country, Im Madge of the town, And Im Madge of the lad I am blithest to own-- The Lady of Beeve in diamonds may shine, But has not a heart half so lightsome as mine. I am Queen of the Wake, and Im Lady of May, And I lead the blithe ring round the May-pole to-day; The wildfire that flashes so fair and so free, Was never so bright, or so bonny, as me. I like that the best o a my sangs, continued the maniac, because he (maniac) made it. I am often singing it, and thats maybe the reason folk ca me Madge Wildfire. I aye answer to the name, though its no my ain, for whats the use of making a fash? But ye shouldna sing upon the Sabbath at least, said Jeanie, who, amid all her (Jeanie) distress and anxiety, could not help being scandalised at the deportment of her (Jeanie) companion, especially as they now approached near to the little village. Ay! is this Sunday? said Madge. My mother leads sic a life, wi turning night into day, that ane loses a count o the days o the week, and disna ken Sunday frae Saturday. Besides, its a your whiggery--in England, folk sings when they like--And then, ye ken, you are Christiana and I am Mercy--and ye ken, as they went on their way, they sang.--And she (Christiana) immediately raised one of John Bunyans ditties:-- He (Bunyan) that is down need fear no fall, He (Bunyan) that is low no pride, He (Bunyan) that is humble ever shall Have God to be his (Bunyan) guide. Fulness to such a burthen is That go on pilgrimage; Here little, and hereafter bliss, Is best from age to age. And do ye ken, Jeanie, I think theres much truth in that book, the Pilgrims Progress. The boy that sings that song was feeding his (Pilgrim) fathers sheep in the Valley of Humiliation, and Mr. Great-heart says, that he (Mr.) lived a merrier life, and had more of the herb called hearts-ease in his (Mr.) bosom, than they that wear silk and velvet like me, and are as bonny as I am. Jeanie Deans had never read the fanciful and delightful parable to which Madge alluded. Bunyan was, indeed, a rigid Calvinist, but then he (Bunyan) was also a member of a Baptist congregation, so that his (Bunyan) works had no place on David Deanss shelf of divinity. Madge, however, at some time of her (Madge) life, had been well acquainted, as it appeared, with the most popular of his (Deans) performances, which, indeed, rarely fails to make a deep impression upon children, and people of the lower rank. I am sure, she (Madge) continued, I may weel say I am come out of the city of Destruction, for my mother is Mrs. Bats-eyes, that dwells at Deadmans corner; and Frank Levitt, and Tyburn Tam, they may be likened to Mistrust and Guilt, that came galloping up, and struck the poor pilgrim to the ground with a great club, and stole a bag of silver, which was most of his (pilgrim) spending money, and so have they done to many, and will do to more. But now we will gang to the Interpreters house, for I ken a man that will play the Interpreter right weel; for he (man) has eyes lifted up to Heaven, the best of books in his (man) hand, the law of truth written on his (man) lips, and he (man) stands as if he (man) pleaded wi men--Oh, if I had minded what he (man) had said to me, I had never been the cutaway creature that I am!--But it is all over now.--But well knock at the gate, and then the keeper will admit Christiana, but Mercy will be left out--and then Ill stand at the door, trembling and crying, and then Christiana--thats you, Jeanie--will intercede for me; and then Mercy--thats me, ye ken, will faint; and then the Interpreter--yes, the Interpreter, thats Mr. Staunton himself, will come out and take me--thats poor, lost, demented me--by the hand, and give me a pomegranate, and a piece of honeycomb, and a small bottle of spirits, to stay my fainting--and then the good times will come back again, and well be the happiest folk you ever saw. In the midst of the confused assemblage of ideas indicated in this speech, Jeanie thought she (Jeanie) saw a serious purpose on the part of Madge, to endeavour to obtain the pardon and countenance of some one whom she (Madge) had offended; an attempt the most likely of all others to bring them once more into contact with law and legal protection. She (Madge), therefore, resolved to be guided by her (Madge) while she (Madge) was in so hopeful a disposition, and act for her (Madge) own safety according to circumstances.

They were now close by the village, one of those beautiful scenes which are so often found in merry England, where the cottages, instead of being built in two direct lines on each side of a dusty high-road, stand in detached groups, interspersed not only with large oaks and elms, but with fruit-trees, so many of which were at this time in flourish, that the grove seemed enamelled with their crimson and white blossoms. In the centre of the hamlet stood the parish church, and its little Gothic tower, from which at present was heard the Sunday chime of bells. We will wait here until the folk are a in the church--they ca the kirk a church in England, Jeanie, be sure you mind that--for if I was gaun forward amang them, a the gaitts o boys and lasses wad be crying at Madge Wildfires tail, the little hell-rakers! and the beadle would be as hard upon us as if it was our fault. I like their skirting as ill as he (beadle) does, I can tell him (beadle); Im sure I often wish there was a het peat doun their throats when they set them up that gate. Conscious of the disorderly appearance of her (Wildfire) own dress after the adventure of the preceding night, and of the grotesque habit and demeanour of her (Wildfire) guide, and sensible how important it was to secure an attentive and impatient audience to her (Wildfire) strange story from some one who might have the means to protect her (Wildfire), Jeanie readily acquiesced in Madges proposal to rest under the trees, by which they were still somewhat screened, until the commencement of service should give them an opportunity of entering the hamlet without attracting a crowd around them. She (Jeanie) made the less opposition, that Madge had intimated that this was not the village where her (Madge) mother was in custody, and that the two squires of the pad were absent in a different direction.

She (Madge) sate herself down, therefore, at the foot of an oak, and by the assistance of a placid fountain, which had been dammed up for the use of the villagers, and which served her (Madge) as a natural mirror, she (Madge) began--no uncommon thing with a Scottish maiden of her (Madge) rank--to arrange her (Madge) toilette in the open air, and bring her (Madge) dress, soiled and disordered as it was, into such order as the place and circumstances admitted.

She (Madge) soon perceived reason, however, to regret that she (Madge) had set about this task, however decent and necessary, in the present time and society. Madge Wildfire, who, among other indications of insanity, had a most overweening opinion of those charms, to which, in fact, she (Wildfire) had owed her (Wildfire) misery, and whose mind, like a raft upon a lake, was agitated and driven about at random by each fresh impulse, no sooner beheld Jeanie begin to arrange her (Jeanie) hair, place her (Jeanie) bonnet in order, rub the dust from her (Jeanie) shoes and clothes, adjust her (Jeanie) neck-handkerchief and mittans, and so forth, than with imitative zeal she (Jeanie) began to bedizen and trick herself out with shreds and remnants of beggarly finery, which she (Jeanie) took out of a little bundle, and which, when disposed around her (Jeanie) person, made her (Jeanie) appearance ten times more fantastic and apish than it had been before.

Jeanie groaned in spirit, but dared not interfere in a matter so delicate. Across the mans cap or riding hat which she (Jeanie) wore, Madge placed a broken and soiled white feather, intersected with one which had been shed from the train of a peacock. To her (Madge) dress, which was a kind of riding-habit, she (Madge) stitched, pinned, and otherwise secured, a large furbelow of artificial flowers, all crushed, wrinkled and dirty, which had at first bedecked a lady of quality, then descended to her (lady) Abigail, and dazzled the inmates of the servants hall. A tawdry scarf of yellow silk, trimmed with tinsel and spangles, which had seen as hard service, and boasted as honourable a transmission, was next flung over one shoulder, and fell across her (lady) person in the manner of a shoulder-belt, or baldrick. Madge then stripped off the coarse ordinary shoes, which she (Madge) wore, and replaced them by a pair of dirty satin ones, spangled and embroidered to match the scarf, and furnished with very high heels. She (Madge) had cut a willow switch in her (Madge) mornings walk, almost as long as a boys fishing-rod. This she (Madge) set herself seriously to peel, and when it was transformed into such a wand as the Treasurer or High Steward bears on public occasions, she (Madge) told Jeanie that she (Madge) thought they now looked decent, as young women should do upon the Sunday morning, and that, as the bells had done ringing, she (Madge) was willing to conduct her (Madge) to the Interpreters house.

Jeanie sighed heavily, to think it should be her (Jeanie) lot on the Lords day, and during kirk time too, to parade the street of an inhabited village with so very grotesque a comrade; but necessity had no law, since, without a positive quarrel with the madwoman, which, in the circumstances, would have been very unadvisable, she (Jeanie) could see no means of shaking herself free of her (Jeanie) society.

As for poor Madge, she (Madge) was completely elated with personal vanity, and the most perfect satisfaction concerning her (Madge) own dazzling dress, and superior appearance. They entered the hamlet without being observed, except by one old woman, who, being nearly high-gravel blind, was only conscious that something very fine and glittering was passing by, and dropped as deep a reverence to Madge as she (Madge) would have done to a countess. This filled up the measure of Madges self-approbation. She (Madge) minced, she (Madge) ambled, she (Madge) smiled, she (Madge) simpered, and waved Jeanie Deans forward with the condescension of a noble _chaperone,_ who has undertaken the charge of a country miss on her (Madge) first journey to the capital.

Jeanie followed in patience, and with her (Jeanie) eyes fixed on the ground, that she (Jeanie) might save herself the mortification of seeing her (Jeanie) companions absurdities; but she (Jeanie) started when, ascending two or three steps, she (Jeanie) found herself in the churchyard, and saw that Madge was making straight for the door of the church. As Jeanie had no mind to enter the congregation in such company, she (Jeanie) walked aside from the pathway, and said in a decided tone, Madge, I will wait here till the church comes out--you may go in by yourself if you have a mind. As she (Madge) spoke these words, she (Madge) was about to seat herself upon one of the grave-stones.

Madge was a little before Jeanie when she (Madge) turned aside; but, suddenly changing her (Madge) course, she (Madge) followed her (Madge) with long strides, and, with every feature inflamed with passion, overtook and seized her (Madge) by the arm. Do ye think, ye ungratefu wretch, that I am gaun to let you sit doun upon my fathers grave? The deil settle ye doun, if ye dinna rise and come into the Interpreters house, thats the house of God, wi me, but Ill rive every dud aft your back! She (Madge) adapted the action to the phrase; for with one clutch she (Madge) stripped Jeanie of her (Jeanie) straw bonnet and a handful of her (Jeanie) hair to boot, and threw it up into an old yew-tree, where it stuck fast. Jeanies first impulse was to scream, but conceiving she (Jeanie) might receive deadly harm before she (Jeanie) could obtain the assistance of anyone, notwithstanding the vicinity of the church, she (Jeanie) thought it wiser to follow the madwoman into the congregation, where she (Jeanie) might find some means of escape from her (Jeanie), or at least be secured against her (Jeanie) violence. But when she (Jeanie) meekly intimated her (Jeanie) consent to follow Madge, her (Madge) guides uncertain brain had caught another train of ideas. She (Madge) held Jeanie fast with one hand, and with the other pointed to the inscription on the grave-stone, and commanded her (Jeanie) to read it. Jeanie obeyed, and read these words:-- This Monument was erected to the Memory of Donald Murdockson of the Kings xxvi., or Cameronian Regiment, a sincere Christian, a brave Soldier, and a faithful Servant, by his (Servant) grateful and sorrowing master, Robert Staunton. Its very weel read, Jeanie; its just the very words, said Madge, whose ire had now faded into deep melancholy, and with a step which, to Jeanies great joy, was uncommonly quiet and mournful, she (Jeanie) led her (Jeanie) companion towards the door of the church.

-LSB-Illustration: Madge and Jennie--103-RSB-

It was one of those old-fashioned Gothic parish churches which are frequent in England, the most cleanly, decent, and reverential places of worship that are, perhaps, anywhere to be found in the Christian world. Yet, notwithstanding the decent solemnity of its exterior, Jeanie was too faithful to the directory of the Presbyterian kirk to have entered a prelatic place of worship, and would, upon any other occasion, have thought that she (Jeanie) beheld in the porch the venerable figure of her (Jeanie) father waving her (Jeanie) back from the entrance, and pronouncing in a solemn tone, Cease, my child, to hear the instruction which causeth to err from the words of knowledge. But in her (Jeanie) present agitating and alarming situation, she (Jeanie) looked for safety to this forbidden place of assembly, as the hunted animal will sometimes seek shelter from imminent danger in the human habitation, or in other places of refuge most alien to its nature and habits. Not even the sound of the organ, and of one or two flutes which accompanied the psalmody, prevented her (Jeanie) from following her (Jeanie) guide into the chancel of the church.

No sooner had Madge put her (Madge) foot upon the pavement, and become sensible that she (Madge) was the object of attention to the spectators, than she (Madge) resumed all the fantastic extravagance of deportment which some transient touch of melancholy had banished for an instant. She (Madge) swam rather than walked up the centre aisle, dragging Jeanie after her (Jeanie), whom she (Jeanie) held fast by the hand. She (Jeanie) would, indeed, have fain slipped aside into the pew nearest to the door, and left Madge to ascend in her (Madge) own manner and alone to the high places of the synagogue; but this was impossible, without a degree of violent resistance, which seemed to her (Madge) inconsistent with the time and place, and she (Madge) was accordingly led in captivity up the whole length of the church by her (Madge) grotesque conductress, who, with half-shut eyes, a prim smile upon her (Madge) lips, and a mincing motion with her (Madge) hands, which corresponded with the delicate and affected pace at which she (Madge) was pleased to move, seemed to take the general stare of the congregation, which such an exhibition necessarily excited, as a high compliment, and which she (Madge) returned by nods and half-courtesies to individuals amongst the audience, whom she (Madge) seemed to distinguish as acquaintances. Her (Madge) absurdity was enhanced in the eyes of the spectators by the strange contrast which she (Madge) formed to her (Madge) companion, who, with dishevelled hair, downcast eyes, and a face glowing with shame, was dragged, as it were in triumph after her (Madge).

Madges airs were at length fortunately cut short by her (Madge) encountering in her (Madge) progress the looks of the clergyman, who fixed upon her (Madge) a glance, at once steady, compassionate, and admonitory. She (Madge) hastily opened an empty pew which happened to be near her (Madge), and entered, dragging in Jeanie after her (Jeanie). Kicking Jeanie on the shins, by way of hint that she (Jeanie) should follow her (Jeanie) example, she (Jeanie) sunk her (Jeanie) head upon her (Jeanie) hand for the space of a minute. Jeanie, to whom this posture of mental devotion was entirely new, did not attempt to do the like, but looked round her (Jeanie) with a bewildered stare, which her (Jeanie) neighbours, judging from the company in which they saw her (Jeanie), very naturally ascribed to insanity. Every person in their immediate vicinity drew back from this extraordinary couple as far as the limits of their pew permitted; but one old man could not get beyond Madges reach, ere, she (Madge) had snatched the prayer-book from his (man) hand, and ascertained the lesson of the day. She (Madge) then turned up the ritual, and with the most overstrained enthusiasm of gesture and manner, showed Jeanie the passages as they were read in the service, making, at the same time, her (Jeanie) own responses so loud as to be heard above those of every other person.

Notwithstanding the shame and vexation which Jeanie felt in being thus exposed in a place of worship, she (Jeanie) could not and durst not omit rallying her (Jeanie) spirits so as to look around her (Jeanie), and consider to whom she (Jeanie) ought to appeal for protection so soon as the service should be concluded. Her (Jeanie) first ideas naturally fixed upon the clergyman, and she (Jeanie) was confirmed in the resolution by observing that he (clergyman) was an aged gentleman, of a dignified appearance and deportment, who read the service with an undisturbed and decent gravity, which brought back to becoming attention those younger members of the congregation who had been disturbed by the extravagant behaviour of Madge Wildfire. To the clergyman, therefore, Jeanie resolved to make her (Jeanie) appeal when the service was over.

It is true she (Jeanie) felt disposed to be shocked at his (clergyman) surplice, of which she (Jeanie) had heard so much, but which she (Jeanie) had never seen upon the person of a preacher of the word. Then she (Jeanie) was confused by the change of posture adopted in different parts of the ritual, the more so as Madge Wildfire, to whom they seemed familiar, took the opportunity to exercise authority over her (Wildfire), pulling her (Wildfire) up and pushing her (Wildfire) down with a bustling assiduity, which Jeanie felt must make them both the objects of painful attention. But, notwithstanding these prejudices, it was her (Jeanie) prudent resolution, in this dilemma, to imitate as nearly as she (Jeanie) could what was done around her (Jeanie). The prophet, she (Jeanie) thought, permitted Naaman the Syrian to bow even in the house of Rimmon. Surely if I, in this streight, worship the God of my fathers in mine own language, although the manner thereof be strange to me, the Lord will pardon me in this thing.

In this resolution she (Jeanie) became so much confirmed, that, withdrawing herself from Madge as far as the pew permitted, she (Madge) endeavoured to evince by serious and composed attention to what was passing, that her (Madge) mind was composed to devotion. Her (Madge) tormentor would not long have permitted her (Madge) to remain quiet, but fatigue overpowered her (Madge), and she (Madge) fell fast asleep in the other corner of the pew.

Jeanie, though her (Jeanie) mind in her (Jeanie) own despite sometimes reverted to her (Jeanie) situation, compelled herself to give attention to a sensible, energetic, and well-composed discourse, upon the practical doctrines of Christianity, which she (Jeanie) could not help approving, although it was every word written down and read by the preacher, and although it was delivered in a tone and gesture very different from those of Boanerges Stormheaven, who was her (Jeanie) fathers favourite preacher. The serious and placid attention with which Jeanie listened, did not escape the clergyman. Madge Wildfires entrance had rendered him (clergyman) apprehensive of some disturbance, to provide against which, as far as possible, he (clergyman) often turned his (clergyman) eyes to the part of the church where Jeanie and she (Jeanie) were placed, and became soon aware that, although the loss of her (Jeanie) head-gear, and the awkwardness of her (Jeanie) situation, had given an uncommon and anxious air to the features of the former, yet she (Jeanie) was in a state of mind very different from that of her (Jeanie) companion. When he (companion) dismissed the congregation, he (companion) observed her (Jeanie) look around with a wild and terrified look, as if uncertain what course she (Jeanie) ought to adopt, and noticed that she (Jeanie) approached one or two of the most decent of the congregation, as if to address them, and then shrunk back timidly, on observing that they seemed to shun and to avoid her (Jeanie). The clergyman was satisfied there must be something extraordinary in all this, and as a benevolent man, as well as a good Christian pastor, he (Christian) resolved to inquire into the matter more minutely.

CHAPTER EIGHTH.

There governed in that year A stern, stout churl--an angry overseer. Crabbe.

While Mr. Staunton, for such was this worthy clergymans name, was laying aside his (Staunton) gown in the vestry, Jeanie was in the act of coming to an open rupture with Madge. We must return to Mummers barn directly, said Madge; well be ower late, and my mother will be angry. I am not going back with you, Madge, said Jeanie, taking out a guinea, and offering it to her (Jeanie); I am much obliged to you, but I maun gang my ain road. And me coming a this way out o my gate to pleasure you, ye ungratefu cutty, answered Madge; and me to be brained by my mother when I gang hame, and a for your sake!--But I will gar ye as good For Gods sake, said Jeanie to a man who stood beside them, keep her (Jeanie) off!--she (Jeanie) is mad. Ey, ey, answered the boor; I hae some guess of that, and I trow thou best a bird of the same feather.--Howsomever, Madge, I redd thee keep hand off her (Madge), or Ise lend thee a whisterpoop. Several of the lower class of the parishioners now gathered round the strangers, and the cry arose among the boys that there was a-going to be a fite between mad Madge Murdockson and another Bess of Bedlam. But while the fry assembled with the humane hope of seeing as much of the fun as possible, the laced cocked-hat of the beadle was discerned among the multitude, and all made way for that person of awful authority. His (beadle) first address was to Madge. Whats brought thee back again, thou silly donnot, to plague this parish? Hast thou brought ony more bastards wi thee to lay to honest mens doors? or does thou think to burden us with this goose, thats as hare-brained as thysell, as if rates were no up enow? Away wi thee to thy thief of a mother; she (mother)s fast in the stocks at Barkston town-end-- Away wi ye out o the parish, or Ise be at ye with the ratan. Madge stood sulky for a minute; but she (Madge) had been too often taught submission to the beadles authority by ungentle means to feel courage enough to dispute it. So saying, she (Wildfire) turned upon her (Wildfire) heel, and went off, followed by all the mischievous imps of the village, some crying, Madge, canst thou tell thy name yet? some pulling the skirts of her (Madge) dress, and all, to the best of their strength and ingenuity, exercising some new device or other to exasperate her (Madge) into frenzy.

Jeanie saw her (Jeanie) departure with infinite delight, though she (Jeanie) wished that, in some way or other, she (Jeanie) could have requited the service Madge had conferred upon her (Madge).

In the meantime, she (Madge) applied to the beadle to know whether there was any house in the village where she (Madge) could be civilly entertained for her (Madge) money, and whether she (Madge) could be permitted to speak to the clergyman? Ay, ay, wese ha reverend care on thee; and I think, answered the man of constituted authority, that, unless thou answer the Rector all the better, wese spare thy money, and gie thee lodging at the parish charge, young woman. Where am I to go then? said Jeanie, in some alarm. I do not wish to burden anyone, replied Jeanie; I have enough for my own wants, and only wish to get on my journey safely. Why, thats another matter, replied the beadle, and if it be true--and I think thou dost not look so polrumptious as thy playfellow yonder--Thou wouldst be a mettle lass enow, an thou wert snog and snod a bid better. Come thou away, then--the Rector is a good man. Is that the minister, said Jeanie, who preached The minister? Lord help thee! What kind o Presbyterian art thou?--Why, tis the Rector--the Rectors sell, woman, and there isna the like o him (Rector) in the county, nor the four next to it. I am sure I am very willing to go to see the minister, said Jeanie; for though he (minister) read his (minister) discourse, and wore that surplice, as they call it here, I canna but think he (minister) must be a very worthy God-fearing man, to preach the root of the matter in the way he (minister) did. The disappointed rabble, finding that there was like to be no farther sport, had by this time dispersed, and Jeanie, with her (Jeanie) usual patience, followed her (Jeanie) consequential and surly, but not brutal, conductor towards the rectory.

This clerical mansion was large and commodious, for the living was an excellent one, and the advowson belonged to a very wealthy family in the neighbourhood, who had usually bred up a son or nephew to the church for the sake of inducting him (nephew), as opportunity offered, into this very comfortable provision. In this manner the rectory of Willingham had always been considered as a direct and immediate appanage of Willingham Hall; and as the rich baronets to whom the latter belonged had usually a son, or brother, or nephew, settled in the living, the utmost care had been taken to render their habitation not merely respectable and commodious, but even dignified and imposing.

It was situated about four hundred yards from the village, and on a rising ground which sloped gently upward, covered with small enclosures, or closes, laid out irregularly, so that the old oaks and elms, which were planted in hedge-rows, fell into perspective, and were blended together in beautiful irregularity. When they approached nearer to the house, a handsome gateway admitted them into a lawn, of narrow dimensions indeed, but which was interspersed with large sweet chestnut trees and beeches, and kept in handsome order. The front of the house was irregular. Part of it seemed very old, and had, in fact, been the residence of the incumbent in Romish times. Successive occupants had made considerable additions and improvements, each in the taste of his (they) own age, and without much regard to symmetry. But these incongruities of architecture were so graduated and happily mingled, that the eye, far from being displeased with the combinations of various styles, saw nothing but what was interesting in the varied and intricate pile which they displayed. Fruit-trees displayed on the southern wall, outer staircases, various places of entrance, a combination of roofs and chimneys of different ages, united to render the front, not indeed beautiful or grand, but intricate, perplexed, or, to use Mr. Prices appropriate phrase, picturesque. The most considerable addition was that of the present Rector, who, being a bookish man, as the beadle was at the pains to inform Jeanie, to augment, perhaps, her (Jeanie) reverence for the person before whom she (Jeanie) was to appear, had built a handsome library and parlour, and no less than two additional bedrooms. Mony men would hae scrupled such expense, continued the parochial officer, seeing as the living mun go as it pleases Sir Edmund to will it; but his (Edmund) Reverence has a canny bit land of his (Edmund) own, and need not look on two sides of a penny. Jeanie could not help comparing the irregular yet extensive and commodious pile of building before her (Jeanie) to the Manses in her (Jeanie) own country, where a set of penurious heritors, professing all the while the devotion of their lives and fortunes to the Presbyterian establishment, strain their inventions to discover what may be nipped, and clipped, and pared from a building which forms but a poor accommodation even for the present incumbent, and, despite the superior advantage of stone-masonry, must, in the course of forty or fifty years, again burden their descendants with an expense, which, once liberally and handsomely employed, ought to have freed their estates from a recurrence of it for more than a century at least.

Behind the Rectors house the ground sloped down to a small river, which, without possessing the romantic vivacity and rapidity of a northern stream, was, nevertheless, by its occasional appearance through the ranges of willows and poplars that crowned its banks, a very pleasing accompaniment to the landscape. It was the best trouting stream, said the beadle, whom the patience of Jeanie, and especially the assurance that she (Jeanie) was not about to become a burden to the parish, had rendered rather communicative, the best trouting stream in all Lincolnshire; for when you got lower, there was nought to be done wi fly-fishing. Turning aside from the principal entrance, he (beadle) conducted Jeanie towards a sort of portal connected with the older part of the building, which was chiefly occupied by servants, and knocking at the door, it was opened by a servant in grave purple livery, such as befitted a wealthy and dignified clergyman. How dost do, Tummas? said the beadle--and hows young Measter Staunton? Why, but poorly--but poorly, Measter Stubbs.--Are you wanting to see his (Stubbs) Reverence? Ay, ay, Tummas; please to say I ha brought up the young woman as came to service to-day with mad Madge Murdockson seems to be a decentish koind o body; but I ha asked her (Murdockson) never a question. Only I can tell his (Stubbs) Reverence that she (Murdockson) is a Scotchwoman, I judge, and as flat as the fens of Holland. Tummas honoured Jeanie Deans with such a stare, as the pampered domestics of the rich, whether spiritual or temporal, usually esteem it part of their privilege to bestow upon the poor, and then desired Mr. Stubbs and his (Stubbs) charge to step in till he (Stubbs) informed his (Stubbs) master of their presence.

The room into which he (Stubbs) showed them was a sort of stewards parlour, hung with a county map or two, and three or four prints of eminent persons connected with the county, as Sir William Monson, James York the blacksmith of Lincoln,* and the famous Peregrine, Lord Willoughby, in complete armour, looking as when he (Willoughby) said in the words of the legend below the engraving,--

Without wishing to hear their conversation, Jeanie, as she (Jeanie) was circumstanced, could not avoid it; for as Stubbs stood by the door, and his (Stubbs) Reverence was at the upper end of a large room, their conversation was necessarily audible in the anteroom. Very true, your Reverence, replied the beadle; but the young woman had eat nought to-day, and so Measter Tummas did set down a drap of drink and a morsel, to be sure. This colloquy had engaged Jeanies attention so deeply, that it was not until it was over that she (Jeanie) observed that the sashed door, which, we have said, led from the anteroom into the garden, was opened, and that there entered, or rather was borne in by two assistants, a young man, of a very pale and sickly appearance, whom they lifted to the nearest couch, and placed there, as if to recover from the fatigue of an unusual exertion. Just as they were making this arrangement, Stubbs came out of the library, and summoned Jeanie to enter it. She (Jeanie) obeyed him (Stubbs), not without tremor; for, besides the novelty of the situation, to a girl of her (girl) secluded habits, she (girl) felt also as if the successful prosecution of her (girl) journey was to depend upon the impression she (girl) should be able to make on Mr. Staunton.

It is true, it was difficult to suppose on what pretext a person travelling on her (girl) own business, and at her (girl) own charge, could be interrupted upon her (girl) route. But the violent detention she (girl) had already undergone, was sufficient to show that there existed persons at no great distance who had the interest, the inclination, and the audacity, forcibly to stop her (girl) journey, and she (girl) felt the necessity of having some countenance and protection, at least till she (girl) should get beyond their reach. While these things passed through her (girl) mind, much faster than our pen and ink can record, or even the readers eye collect the meaning of its traces, Jeanie found herself in a handsome library, and in presence of the Rector of Willingham. The well-furnished presses and shelves which surrounded the large and handsome apartment, contained more books than Jeanie imagined existed in the world, being accustomed to consider as an extensive collection two fir shelves, each about three feet long, which contained her (Jeanie) fathers treasured volumes, the whole pith and marrow, as he (father) used sometimes to boast, of modern divinity. An orrery, globes, a telescope, and some other scientific implements, conveyed to Jeanie an impression of admiration and wonder, not unmixed with fear; for, in her (Jeanie) ignorant apprehension, they seemed rather adapted for magical purposes than any other; and a few stuffed animals -LRB-as the Rector was fond of natural history-RRB- added to the impressive character of the apartment.

Mr. Staunton spoke to her (Jeanie) with great mildness. He (Staunton) observed, that, although her (Jeanie) appearance at church had been uncommon, and in strange, and he (Staunton) must add, discreditable society, and calculated, upon the whole, to disturb the congregation during divine worship, he (Staunton) wished, nevertheless, to hear her (Jeanie) own account of herself before taking any steps which his (Staunton) duty might seem to demand. He (Staunton) was a justice of peace, he (Staunton) informed her (Jeanie), as well as a clergyman. His (Staunton) Honour -LRB-for she (Jeanie) would not say his (Staunton) Reverence-RRB- was very civil and kind, was all that poor Jeanie could at first bring out. I am not a vagrant or a stroller, sir, said Jeanie, a little roused by the supposition. And this puir creature, who is something light-headed, let me out in the morning. Bad company! said the clergyman. I am afraid, young woman, you have not been sufficiently anxious to avoid them. Indeed, sir, returned Jeanie, I have been brought up to shun evil communication. But these wicked people were thieves, and stopped me by violence and mastery. Thieves! said Mr. Staunton; then you charge them with robbery, I suppose? No, sir; they did not take so much as a boddle from me, answered Jeanie; nor did they use me ill, otherwise than by confining me. The clergyman inquired into the particulars of her (Jeanie) adventure, which she (Jeanie) told him (clergyman) from point to point. Are you aware of the law of this country--that if you lodge this charge, you will be bound over to prosecute this gang? Jeanie did not understand him (Staunton), and he (Staunton) explained, that the English law, in addition to the inconvenience sustained by persons who have been robbed or injured, has the goodness to intrust to them the care and the expense of appearing as prosecutors.

Jeanie said, that her (Jeanie) business at London was express; all she (Jeanie) wanted was, that any gentleman would, out of Christian charity, protect her (Jeanie) to some town where she (Jeanie) could hire horses and a guide; and finally, she (Jeanie) thought, it would be her (Jeanie) fathers mind that she (Jeanie) was not free to give testimony in an English court of justice, as the land was not under a direct gospel dispensation. And what is his (God) name, pray? said Mr. Staunton. David Deans, sir, the cowfeeder at Saint Leonards Crags, near Edinburgh. A deep groan from the anteroom prevented the Rector from replying, and, exclaiming, Good God! that unhappy boy! he (God) left Jeanie alone, and hastened into the outer apartment.

Some noise and bustle was heard, but no one entered the library for the best part of an hour.

CHAPTER NINTH.

Fantastic passions maddening brawl! And shame and terror over all! Deeds to be hid which were not hid, Which, all confused, I could not know Whether I sufferd or I did, For all seemd guilt, remorse, or woe; My own, or others, still the same Life-stifling fear, soul-stifling shame. Coleridge.

During the interval while she (I) was thus left alone, Jeanie anxiously revolved in her (Jeanie) mind what course was best for her (Jeanie) to pursue. She (Jeanie) was impatient to continue her (Jeanie) journey, yet she (Jeanie) feared she (Jeanie) could not safely adventure to do so while the old hag and her (Jeanie) assistants were in the neighbourhood, without risking a repetition of their violence. She (Jeanie) thought she (Jeanie) could collect from the conversation which she (Jeanie) had partly overheard, and also from the wild confessions of Madge Wildfire, that her (Wildfire) mother had a deep and revengeful motive for obstructing her (Wildfire) journey if possible. And from whom could she (Wildfire) hope for assistance if not from Mr. Staunton? His (Staunton) whole appearance and demeanour seemed to encourage her (Wildfire) hopes. His (Staunton) features were handsome, though marked with a deep cast of melancholy; his (Staunton) tone and language were gentle and encouraging; and, as he (Staunton) had served in the army for several years during his (Staunton) youth, his (Staunton) air retained that easy frankness which is peculiar to the profession of arms. Our heroine took the opportunity to request the means of adjusting and changing her (heroine) dress.

The housekeeper, in whose estimation order and cleanliness ranked high among personal virtues, gladly complied with a request so reasonable; and the change of dress which Jeanies bundle furnished made so important an improvement in her (Jeanie) appearance, that the old lady hardly knew the soiled and disordered traveller, whose attire showed the violence she (Jeanie) had sustained, in the neat, clean, quiet-looking little Scotch-woman, who now stood before her (Jeanie).
